Spinning into Inclusion
Ready, Set, Learn!
You will be able to:
• Build a simple circuit to power a motor and make the merry-go-round move.
• Describe how their motorized merry-go-round works using the ideas of motion and electricity. • Identify problems they faced while building and explain how they solved them.
• Design a safe and inclusive merry-go-round that can be used by all children, including those with disabilities. • Use graphs and data to compare how fast the merry-go- round moves and how safe it is.

Laila: “The merry-go-round is hard to push. How can we make it move easier?”
Adam: “What if something pushes it for us?”
Khaled: “Like a machine?”

Why should the merry-go-round move on its own?
Because it’s more fun to ride! Because it would be too hard to push if someone in a wheelchair is on it.
Because it can spin faster by itself!

Hey flriends let’s wrap up!
An electric circuit is like a little road that helps electricity travel from the battery to other parts like lights or motors. When the electricity moves through the wires, it helps the motor turn and make things move — like our merry-go-round!
So, the motor is what makes the merry-go-round spin all by itself, without someone pushing it!
